nodeFaq.title: When is it okay to base social policies on race?

field_question_summary.processed: In the program, you show how race has been used historically to discriminate against minorities. When is it okay to talk about race or use race? Isn't it just as wrong to base policies and laws on race today as it was 50 or even 100 years ago?

field_expert_1.processed: I think the question presumes that we as a society cannot distinguish between really malignant forms of racial exclusion and policies that are designed to assist victims of that same exclusion. As Justice Stevens said in the Adarand case, it presumes that we can't tell the difference between a "No Trespassing" sign and a "Welcome" mat. For example, I think that the American public can understand that there is a significant difference between the many policies in trade unions that previously sought to exclude anyone but white Christian males and those policies and voluntary affirmative action programs in various trade unions today designed to rectify this history of exclusion. What is key is being able to connect the policy, such as affirmative action policy, to the past exclusions. Then you can see that the affirmative policy is merely a mode of undoing privilege and exclusion; i.e., a needed correction, and not a "preference" of any sort.

field_expert_1_answer.processed: I don't think it's a coincidence that there's a movement to not consider race as a relevant category at this time in modern history. Especially in light of recent American history, when people of color have made a lot of progress to really push these issues into the forefront and demand recognition of basic civil rights and equal opportunity. I don't think it's accidental that there's this movement to erase the relevance of race. It certainly was relevant in the past. White people didn't have a problem with using and being invested in racial categories in the past. I think it's worth thinking about why they might be more invested in not taking "race" into consideration today.

field_expert_4_answer.processed: One of the reasons it becomes very slippery to talk about race is because the concept - what it refers to and defines - changes over time. It often operates as a rationale after the fact for things that are ongoing. So this question is actually about how race has been used historically. One way to make it more concrete is to think about different historical uses at different times and to separate out the different dynamics and consequences that spring from each one. How does race operate after World War II, for example, versus after the Civil Rights Act, compared to how it operates today? Locating different uses of race in time and in a specific historical context is important.

backref_field_tags_node_article.title: Racial Preferences for Whites: The Houses That Racism Built

field_short_version.processed: Racism doesn't just come dressed in white sheets or voiced by skinheads, but lies in institutions that, like the FHA, have quietly and often invisibly channeled America's wealth, power, and status disproportionately to white people.

backref_field_tags_node_article.title: A Long History of Racial Preferences: For Whites

field_short_version.processed: 'Colorblind' policies that treat everyone the same, no exceptions for minorities, are often counter-posed against affirmative action. But colorblindness today merely bolsters the unfair advantages that color-coded practices have enabled white Americans.

backref_field_tag_node_faq.title: What does equity look like? (when will racism end?)

field_expert_1.value:
I think the question really needs to be turned around and we need to ask, "When are we going to be rid of racism in U.S. society?" I think the answer to this question serves as the answer for the former question. The idea of a permanent affirmative action policy is used to scare people who might otherwise support affirmative action. Affirmative action opponents play upon fears that proactive measures will become a politically inscribed remedy that society will never be rid of once they are put into place. Past practice has proven that that's just not the case. At the outset of affirmative action programs, women were incredibly underrepresented in fields such as law and medicine and that gap was quickly eliminated within just a couple of years. Since then, in most programs, women (as an aggregate category) no longer benefit from affirmative action. The same thing happened with various subcategories of Asians at schools in the 1970s. For example, Japanese Americans were removed from affirmative action consideration at the UC Berkeley law school. Historically, admissions committees have used representational numbers as a guideline for which groups continue to need affirmative action and which ones do not.

But note that legislation such as the new Ward Connerly initiative (the racial privacy initiative that's actually being renamed the "Information Ban Initiative") seeks to ban the collection of race-based data as an outdated invasion of privacy. Should such an ill-advised measure succeed, it would be impossible to measure progress (or setbacks). If we are supposed to be an egalitarian society, don't we want to know where the racial disparities are? Don't we care that Dorothy Roberts, in her recent book Shattered Bonds, discovered that 95% of all the children in the foster care system in Chicago are black? Or that 42% of the children in the foster care system nationwide are black even though they constitute only 17% of the nation's children? If we do care, then we need to keep records as a measure for devising social policies to address these troubling disparities.

backref_field_tag_node_faq.title: Why do we have to pay for wrongs of the past?

field_expert_1.value: This is a familiar question: "Why am I responsible for the sins of the past?" In terms of slavery, we need to recognize slavery as an important institution upon which America's wealth was built. If we take this view, it's not important whether a white family, or a black family for that matter, arrived in 1700 or in 1965. If we wear cotton blue jeans, if we took out an insurance policy from Aetna, if we buy anything from anyone who has a connection to the industries that were built on slavery, then we benefit from slavery. And since capitalism touches us all, we all bear the stain of slavery and likewise, if you're black in America, regardless of when your ancestors arrived, you live with the stigma of it. And so, if capitalism, compound interest, and the magic of money enables us to enjoy the wealth of America, we're implicated in its past as well.

backref_field_tag_node_faq.title: How do we dispel racist ideology?

field_expert_1.value:
Well first of all we have to understand that it's a rationalization. There are still people who function as if the rationalization is based on truth. There are still people who feel, well, black people have certain kinds of characteristics that I can attribute to them simply because of their race - whether it's genetic or like George says, a product of culture, it's just the way they are.

Now if we realize that all that is a rationalization, that these things happen to people after they're born, not before, that would help. Then we have to understand the destructive effect of that rationalization on the people against which it is directed and on the society as a whole. If we think about the extent to which this society is in need of a variety of talents and abilities, if we think about the extent to which the rationalization that was used to support slavery is now used in today's society to deny large numbers of people opportunities to contribute their talents to society, then we realize the society as a whole suffers because of that. Simply said, we need all the talents Americans can provide. If we make it impossible for all Americans to provide their talents, we're not only hurting those people who have the talents, we're also hurting the society that needs those talents.

backref_field_tag_node_faq.title: Why not base affirmative action on socioeconomic status instead of race?

field_expert_1.value: It's certainly one idea to use class. The advantages are that it preempts a couple of the major criticisms of affirmative action policy as it now stands. If you make it a class-based system, it becomes less obviously coded with race and therefore less stigmatizing. It also might ensure that these policies get to the people who need it the most; i.e., poor minorities. But if class is interpreted in traditional ways (using parental income or education level), you're going to perpetuate the system as it is now. You must factor in wealth or assets in order to address the real roots of disparity. It is in the area of wealth where the greatest disparities exist by race. Today, a typical white family has eight times the wealth of the typical black family - that statistic is not explainable by income or other factors. So if we were to use class instead of race, I would suggest that it be done based primarily on wealth, and secondarily on income and education level. Then you might have a racially progressive policy that's ostensibly colorblind. But if you do it any other way, you're just going to reinforce the existing inequality.

backref_field_tag_node_faq.title: What can individuals do to stop institutional racism?

field_expert_1.value: The most concrete action that any one individual can take is to educate themselves about the ways that race and racism work and to see things in terms of social relations rather than discrete individual acts. Every racial group is always linked to every other racial group. So when you talk about something like white privilege, you have to understand it's a system of inequality that relates groups together. That's a very important part of how institutional racism works: it perpetuates inequality in a way that most people who gain the advantage don't realize. People need to understand these relationships and recognize that if we do the same thing we've always done, we're perpetuating inequality.

backref_field_tag_node_faq.title: How do you enlist support of white people in achieving racial equality?

field_expert_1.value:
What are the effects for non-victims? I think the state of racial politics in this country creates for many privileged people a really significant set of personal and political paradoxes. Most people declare their support for the theory of racial equality: rights and privileges, opportunity, fair treatment. And since the civil rights transformations of the 1950s and '60s, many privileged people, especially whites, think that by respecting the letter of civil rights law and by not engaging in obviously offensive acts of discrimination, they are playing by the rules and promoting equality. Here's the paradox, though: since so many of the mechanisms that discriminate, and so many of the mechanisms that perpetuate inequality are not obvious, many people are actually encouraging and perpetuating this inequality - this same inequality that they claim to oppose. So while many people feel strongly that they are not racist, they nonetheless help perpetuate racial inequality, perhaps unknowingly. That's something people need to think about.

What does the perpetuation of inequality and the denial that it exists do for political culture and daily life in the U.S.? People of color have always organized to protest against racism, and by doing so they have been instrumental in creating a nation that's actually more fair and democratic. And they're very much aware of the systematic discrimination that still exists. So what happens in political debates and in daily life when whites and others ignore these things, when they insist that there is real equality of opportunity? What happens when people who are in these positions of racial privilege ignore inequality or attribute them to culture or effort? If whites and non-whites, generally speaking, have very different interpretations of the meaning of race in the U.S., it is not a very good recipe for real civic debate and for living in a multi-ethnic or multi-racial country. I think that one step towards enlisting people who might lose some of their privileges is to get them to consider this paradox and the impact this paradox has on the culture and politics of race relations in their daily lives.

Also, I think that people in positions of relative privilege, especially racial privilege, need to initiate debates over racial equality. Given what we know about the history of racism, attaining racial equality should not be the responsibility of racial minorities.
